resources.string: To use voice control, say \'menu\', followed by a command. Available commands at present are \'pitch matching\', \'intervals\', \'scales\', \'melodies\', \'terminology\', \'help\', and \'about\'. You can say \'intervals\' or \'melodies\', followed by \'easy\', \'medium\', or \'hard\' to open the exercise with the given difficulty. You can also say \'stop speaking\' to stop the text-to-speech, and \'cancel\' to cancel voice control. Voice control is only available outside of exercises, if you need to quit an exercise use the back button on your device. If you need this help section again at a later time, say \"menu\", followed by \"help\".
This app needs to record audio for voice recognition and the music exercises to work, also this app needs to write to external storage to setup voice recognition.
Try match your pitch with the target pitch!

The intervals exercise has three difficulties: easy, medium, and hard. Each difficulty adds more intervals, and includes the intervals from the lower difficulties. 

Easy starts with four intervals: unision, perfect fourth, perfect fifth, and octave. 

The medium difficulty adds the intervals: major second, minor third, major sixth, and minor sixth. 

The hard difficulty adds the intervals: minor second, augmented fourth, major seventh, and minor seventh.

Each level of difficulty adds new scales to the exercise. 

The easy difficulty will test you on the Major scale and the Pentatonic Major scale. 

Medium will add the scales: Natural Minor, and Pentatonic Minor. 

The hard difficulty will add the scales: Harmonic Minor, and Melodic Minor.

The melodies exercise has three difficulties: easy, medium, and hard. Similar to the scale exercises, each level of difficulty adds more scales, from which the melodies are created. 
The level of difficulty also makes the melodies more challenging by: increasing the length of the melody; increasing the maximum jump between notes in the melody; increasing the range of the melody; and reversing the direction of the melody with increasing chance.

The scales tested for each difficulty are as follows: 

The easy difficulty will test you on the Major scale and the Pentatonic Major scale. 

Medium will add the scales: Natural Minor, and Pentatonic Minor. 

The hard difficulty will add the scales: Harmonic Minor, and Melodic Minor.

Pitch - any single stationary sound, whether it's exactly the same as a note or not (for example, you can have a pitch that sounds exactly the same as an A note, or you could have one that sounds slightly off in pitch) 

Note - A note is the combination of the pitch and duration of a sound. 

Cents - a measure out of one hundred that measures how far away a particular pitch is from a given note. 

Scale - an organized series of notes, from which melodies can be written. 

Melody - A melody is basically a sequence of notes. 
Interval - two difference between two pitches (for example, the interval formed by an A and an A# is a minor second).
